We now use the relation \(\ \ A=PDP^{-1}\)  to obtain a formula for powers of \(A\) in terms of the easily calculated powers of the diagonal matrix \(D\):

\begin{align*} A^ = A \cdot A & = (PDP^{-1})(PDP^{-1}) \\ & = PD(P^{-1}P)DP^{-1} \\ & = PDIDP^{-1} \\ & = PD^2P^{-1} \end{align*}

Similarly,

\begin{align*} A^3 = A^2 \cdot A & (PD^2P^{-1})(PDP^{-1}) \\ & = PD^2(P^{-1}P)DP^{-1} \\ & = PD^3P^{-1} \end{align*}

The general result is given in the following Key Point:

Key Point

For a matrix \(A\) with distinct eigenvalues \(\lambda_1,\lambda_2,\dots ,\lambda_n\) and associated eigenvectors \(\underline{x}_1, \underline{x}_2,\dots ,\underline{x}_n\), if

\[P=[\underline{x}_1 : \underline{x}_2 : \ \cdots\ : \underline{x}_n]\]

then \(D=P^{-1}AP\) is a diagonal matrix such that \[ D=\left[\begin{matrix}\lambda_1&&&&\\ &\lambda_2&&&\\ &&\ddots &&\\ &&&\lambda_n\end{matrix}\right]\qquad\text{and}\qquad A^k=PD^kP^{-1}\]

Example

If \(A=\left[\begin{array}{cc}2&3\\ 3&2\end{array}\right]\), find \(A^{23}\). (Use the results of the previous Example.)

Solution

We know from the previous Example that if \(P=\left[\begin{array}{rr}1&1\\-1&1\end{array}\right]\) then \( P^{-1}AP=\left[\begin{array}{rr}-1&0\\ 0&5\end{array}\right]= D\) where \(P^{-1}=\dfrac{1}{2}\left[\begin{array}{rr}\hfill 1&\hfill -1\\ \hfill 1&\hfill 1\end{array}\right]\).

Therefore,

\(A=PDP^{-1}\)   and   \(A^{23}=PD^{23}P^{-1}\)   using the general result in the Key Point, i.e.,

\[A^{23}= \dfrac{1}{2} \left[\begin{array}{rr}\hfill 1&\hfill 1\\ \hfill -1&\hfill 1\end{array}\right] \left[\begin{array}{rr}\hfill -1&\hfill 0\\ \hfill 0&\hfill 5^{23}\end{array}\right] \left[\begin{array}{rr}\hfill 1&\hfill -1\\ \hfill 1&\hfill 1\end{array}\right]\]

which is easily evaluated, especially compared to calculating the product \(A^{23}\) directly!
